sections.heading: 1. Introduction
sections.text:
With the rapid development of the 21st century global economy the great depletion of fossil fuel resources, increasing environmental pollution and a deepening energy crisis have triggered great interest in searching for clean energy solutions. Photocatalysis is a leader among advanced sustainable energy technologies, which enables the harvesting of optical energy (typically in the ultra-violet and visible regions of solar spectra) via semiconductor materials and converts it into chemical energy [1, 2], and endless efforts have been expended in making the most of the enormous, inexhaustible and environmentally nonhazardous solar energy through photocatalysis, for significant applications including not only to treat environmental pollution [3–6], but also to generate hydrogen energy from water under sunlight irradiation [7–10]. Titanium dioxide (TiO2) has been long regarded as one of the most promising photocatalysts with merits such as high reactivity, good stability, eco-nontoxicity, cost-effectiveness etc, and TiO2 nanomaterials had been mainly applied in products such as interior decorations and personal care, until in 1972 Fujimasha and Honda firstly used TiO2 electrode to photocatalyze water splitting [11]. Since then, numerous TiO2 nanomaterials and TiO2 based composite nanomaterials have been designed and synthesized [4, 12–14]. However, several factors have limited its practical applications, such as wide bandgaps (3.2 eV for anatase and 3.0 eV for rutile) and the rapid recombination of photogenerated electron–hole pairs. Over the past few years, considerable effort has been made to modify the bandgap of TiO2 and enhance its photocatalytic activity under visible light illumination; for example, doping, namely, introducing alien atoms or compounds into the TiO2 matrix to alter the electronic structure for both enhancing visible light absorption and charge carrier transfer. In detail,

doping of metal elements (such as Fe, Co, Cr, Ni, and Mo) [15– 22] or non-metal elements (such as N, C, F, and S) [1, 23–28], co-doping of metal and non-metal elements (such as Mo + C, Fe + N, Mo + S, and Co + N, S) [29–31], self-doping (introducing intrinsic defects, such as oxygen vacancies and Ti3+) [32–40], coupling with small bandgap semiconductors (such as CdS and ZnO) or compositing with carbon nanomaterials like graphene [36, 41–50], can all trigger visible-light activity. Besides, modifying their phases, morphology, structure, and porosity can also affect their photochemical activities [51–53].
In this review we present a short introduction to the physical and electronic properties of TiO2, its photocatalytic mechanisms, and some recent examples of various TiO2 nanomaterials used for photocatalysis; these examples include 0, 1, 2, 3D, faceted, defected, composited, and hydrogenated TiO2 nanomaterials. As TiO2 photocatalysis is an extensively studied area, this review cannot cover the progress made in this field in its entirety, but, rather, will provide some basic information for researchers in this field.

sections.heading: 2.1. Structural properties
sections.text:
There are four common crystalline phases of TiO2: anatase, rutile, brookite, and TiO2(B) [54]. As shown in figure  1, all of these phases consist of TiO6 octahedra, but differ in both the distortion of their octahedra units and the manner in which they share edges and corners [42]. For anatase, four of the eight neighbors of each octahedral share edges; the subsequent others share corners. The corner-sharing octahedron forms the (0 0 1) planes and their edges connect with the plane of the octahedron below [55]. In rutile, the octahedral structure shares two edges and eight corners. The corner-sharing is along the [1 1 0] direction and stacks with their long axis alternation by 90° [55].
The Ti–O bond lengths are 1.937 and 1.966 Ǻ for anatase and 1.946 and 1.983 Ǻ for rutile in the equatorial and axial directions, respectively [55]. The different structural arrangements result in different space groups. For brookite, both corners and edges are connected [56, 57]. TiO2(B) is mainly derived from the layered titanates. The structure of TiO2(B) is composed of corrugated sheets consisting of both edges and corners shared by the TiO6 octahedra [58].

sections.heading: 2.2. Electronic properties
sections.text: The electronic structure of TiO2 has been extensively studied using ab initio methodology [59]. Here, we focus on anatase and rutile—the more widely studied phases of TiO2. Their differences in lattice structures cause different densities and electronic band structures, leading to different bandgaps. For bulk materials, the bandgap for anatase TiO2 is approximately 3.20 eV (corresponding to 384 nm) and the bandgap of rutile is 3.02 eV (corresponding to 410 nm). The electronic structure of both phases of TiO2 can be understood with molecular band theory [59]. At the top of the valence band maximum (VBM) is the nonbonding O p orbital (out of the Ti3O cluster plane), where at the bottom of the conduction band maximum (CBM) are the nonbonding Ti dxy states. For rutile, the Ti dxy orbitals at CBM are relatively isolated, while the t2g orbitals of the CBM provide the metal–metal interaction with a smaller distance of 2.96 Å. The conductive band width of anatase is thus smaller than that of rutile, resulting in a slightly wider bandgap of 3.2 eV as compared to 3.0 eV for rutile.

sections.heading: 3. Photocatalysis fundamentals
sections.text:
The conduction band of TiO2 is formed by the lowest unoccupied molecular orbitals (LUMO) and the valence band is formed by the highest occupied molecular orbitals (HOMO).
Topical Review
No electron states exist between the conduction band and valence band—the energy separation between these two states is known as the bandgap (or energy gap). The electronic band structure influences the photon absorption process and redox reaction ability for photocatalysis. As illustrated in figure 2, only photons with energy pertaining to that of the bandgap can be absorbed [60]. Upon exposure to the required photon energy, electrons in the valence band will be excited to the conduction band while leaving positively charged holes in the valence band [60]. An electron–hole pair will therefore be generated, as expressed in equation (1) [61].

These charge carriers have three possible fates: (i) be captured and trapped by defect sites within or on the surface of the material, (ii) recombine and release energy in the form of heat or light, or iii) migrate to the surface and generate radical species in equations (2)–(4) [61]. Electron paramagnetic resonance studies have found that electrons are trapped by Ti atoms, forming two TiIII centers, while holes are trapped as O centered radicals covalently linked to surface Ti atoms and localized differently at defect sites in TiO2 nanoparticles [62]. Consequences (i) and (ii) are known as ‘deactivation processes’ since these electron–hole pairs do not play any part in photocatalysis. Therefore, the photocatalytic efficiency is determined by inhibiting process (i) and (ii), while enhancing process (iii) at optimized conditions.
Two strategies are commonly adopted to improve the photocatalytic property of TiO2 nanomaterials: we can either increase the amount of charge carriers produced upon irradiation by lowering the bandgap, or engineer the surface to prevent the recombination of electron–hole pairs; here we address
the first strategy. To enhance the light-harvesting capability on the surface, we need the material to absorb photons with lower energy (preferably in the visible region) [63]. The bandgap can be engineered and narrowed down by doping other elements or undergoing special treatments, such as dye sensitization. Cation doping (e.g. Cr3+, Fe3+, Co2+, Ni2+, V5+) can replace Ti with cations and introduce an intermediate impurity level in the energy band which acts as either an electron donor or acceptor to enable visible light absorption [2–8]. Conversely, anion doping (e.g. B, C, N, F, P, S) replaces the O in TiO2 with nonmetal components. Although this scarcely affects the conduction band, it decreases the bandgap by reconstructing the valence band and shifting it upward [10–15, 64]. Selfdoping, another possible bandgap engineering method, is a dopant-free treatment that partially reduces Ti4+ to Ti3+ and creates O vacancies on the surface or throughout the material. Such treatments not only decrease the bandgap of TiO2, but also minimize the drawbacks caused by introducing impurities, such as crystal instability and increased recombination sites [65, 66]. Alternatively, dye sensitization can also extend the light harvest of TiO2 nanomaterials to the visible region. As shown in figure 3, the dye molecules adsorbed onto the semiconductor material (TiO2) surface, rather than the surface itself, will absorb photons, exciting and injecting electrons into the conduction band of the TiO2 for the reduction reaction on the TiO2 surface. Excited dye molecules, in order to maintain electric neutrality, will capture the electrons from a sacrificial reagent and continue to funnel electrons into the semiconductor’s conduction band [54].
Increasing the lifetime of charge carriers by facilitating charge carrier migration to a material’s surface may shorten their travel distance and prevent recombination. For example, through a process known as high temperature annealing, material crystallinity can be greatly enhanced to diminish defects inside. Also, TiO2 nanomaterials synthesized into 1D morphologies (e.g. nanowires, nanobelts) [67] or 2D morphologies (nanosheets) [68] will generally have improved charge mobility and transfer efficiency than 0D ones. Increasing the specific surface area or applying surface functionalization treatments will provide more possible active reaction sites for photocatalysis. The formation of junctions including heterojunctions, phase junctions, and Schottky junctions within nanomaterials can provide built-in assistance of electron–hole pair separation [69–71]. In the following sections we detail the mechanism by which charge carriers drive photocatalytic reactions.

sections.heading: 3.1. Photocatalytic decomposition
sections.text:
Photocatalytic decomposition of organic compounds, especially those that are biohazardous in air or water, are of great significance for environmental protection. TiO2 nanomat erials provide a green approach to convert a number of organic pollutants into CO2 and H2O under light illumination [2]. Electrons generated by the photon-induced electron–hole pairs are captured by the oxygen dissolved in water to form the per oxygen radical, −O2 , seen in equation (5) [2]; oxidative holes can either directly decompose the organic compounds adsorbed on the TiO2 surface or oxidize the OH− anions or H2O molecules into hydroxy radicals, ⋅OH, which then undergo a series of chemical steps (equations (6)–(8)), that generate strong oxidizing species that decompose organic pollutants into harmless CO2 and H2O [2].

For example, the syntheses of high specific surface areas facilitate the adsorption of organic pollutant molecules to the surface for reaction, but the larger surface area may introduce more defect sites for charge carriers to recombine. As another example, high temperature annealing can improve crystalline and limit the number of defect sites, but at the cost of decreasing the surface area by merging small grains or particles into bigger ones. A phase mixing approach is a promising strategy for enhancing charge separation in TiO2 and hence increasing photocatalytic reactivity. P25 is a wellknown mix-phase photocatalyst, but its photocatalytic activity is still not enough for visible light application. Many studies have focused on extending the optical absorption. A series of doped TiO2 nanoparticles does extend the absorption spectrum to visible region, and obtain excellent photocatalytic degradation activity [27, 28, 72]. As the TiO2 powder is difficult to separate from treated water, it would cause secondary nano-contamination. Schmuki, Li, and Zhang’s groups mainly committed to prepare TiO2 nanotubes, nanorods, and nanofibers on Ti substrate, which not only show high and stable photocatalytic activity under visible light, but also can be easily recycled [32, 51, 73–75].

sections.heading: 3.2. Photocatalytic water splitting
sections.text:
Photocatalytic water splitting was first discovered by Fujimasha and Honda using the TiO2 electrode in 1972 [11, 76]. Since then further efforts have been made on the study of the mechanism and performance improvement in the hopes of utilizing water as a clean, renewable energy source [77]. The bandgap width and potentials are important
to overall water splitting; the bottom of the conduction band has to be more negative than the reduction potential of H+/H2 (0 V versus NHE, pH = 7), while the top of the valence band has to be more positive than the oxidation potential of O2/H2O (1.23 V versus NHE, pH = 7). However, this is only the thermodynamic requirement of the band structure. Its water-splitting performance is also influenced by more complicated factors such as crystallinity, surface area, surface functioning groups, and number of active sites. Moreover, the water-splitting reaction also changes the material surface chemistry and local pH environment on a TiO2 electrode [78]. A basic set-up for aqueous photocatalytic water splitting is shown in figure  4 [79]. When the TiO2 photoanode is illuminated, electrons excited to the conduction band will transfer to the Pt photocathode where protons are reduced to molecular hydrogen [79]. Meanwhile, the holes left on the photoanode surface oxidize water and produce molecular oxygen. A proton exchange membrane is placed in the middle to separate each half-reaction and balance the local pH environment. The half-reaction equations are written as equations (9) and (10) [76]:
    →  +− +e4 4H 2H .2 (9)
    →    + ++ +h4 2H O O 4H .2 2 (10) Many studies have shown that it is difficult to achieve
overall water splitting into H2 and O2 by pure TiO2 photocatalysis in a simple aqueous system, due to the rapid electron– hole recombination phenomena. To overcome this drawback, sacrificial agents, such as reducing agents, are added to the aqueous solution. Sacrificial agents can continuously and irreversibly be reduced by the photogenerated holes instead of water, enhancing the H2 evolution reaction. Methanol, ethanol, EDTA, S2−, I−, −IO3 , CN
−, Ag+, and Fe3+ have all been applied as sacrificial agents [80]. Wu’s group reported a wetchemistry method for anisotropic growth of TiO2 onto gold nanorods by using CnTAB as a soft template and by controlling the degree of hydrolysis of TiCl3 [81]. The as-prepared nanomaterials structure satisfied the electron refilling requirement and exhibited plasmon-enhanced hydrogen production under visible and NIR light irradiation [81].

sections.heading: 3.3. Photocatalytic CO2 reduction
sections.text:
Fujishima and Honda further reported the photoelectrocatalytic reduction of CO2 into organic compounds, such as formaldehyde, methyl alcohol, and methane, with watersuspended photocatalysts, including, but not limited to, TiO2, ZnO, WO3, SiC, CdS, and GaP [82]. It presented an alternative solution to global energy issues and introduced the possibility that solar energy can be stored to regenerate fuels sustainably with abundant CO2. Similar to water splitting, photocatalytic CO2 reduction also requires an aqueous medium. Electrons and holes generated from the watersplitting reaction supply the driving force for the reduction of CO2, in the reaction steps of which are outlined in equations (11)–(14) [54]:
( )  →+ ++ −eCO aq 2H 2 HCOOH.2 (11)
  →  + + ++ −eHCOOH 2H 2 HCHO H O.2 (12)
  →+ ++ −eHCHO 2H 2 CH OH.3 (13)
  →  + + ++ −eCH OH 2H 2 CH H O.3 4 2 (14) The charge transfer rates between photogenerated carriers and species in solution depend on the difference in the reduction potential between the semiconductor and the redox agents [82]. However, photocatalytic CO2 reduction has a more negative reduction potential than water splitting and the conversion efficiencies of various advanced photocatalytic materials, structures, or systems reported to date are not feasible [83–85]; the reduction of CO2 is much harder than that of the proton. The transfer of four electrons is required in water splitting to evolve H2, whereas CO2 reduction requires six and eight electrons to generate the reduced products of methanol and methane, respectively. Furthermore, CO2 reduction requires a large amount of energy to break two C=O double bonds in a molecule, and if a fuel of longer carbon chain molecules is desired, a C–C bond formation step will also need to be included in the process; this is no easy feat. Finally, CO2 and protons compete for electrons in aqueous media. This competition for reduction may limit the degree to which CO2 is reduced, generating undesirable organic compounds.
TiO2 is a promising photocatalyst for CO2 photoreduction due to its favorable band edges because TiO2 has a higher conduction band edge, which will promote the reaction of CO2 reduction with H2O which has a high reduction potential. Yan et al reported that slightly hydrogenated TiO2 nanoparticles synthesized by H2 plasma treatment at 150 °C exhibited enhanced CO2 photoreduction activity [86]. Xin et al reported that the black Brookite TiO2 single-crystalline nanosheets prepared with the oxidation-based hydrothermal reaction method combined with post-annealing treatment showed outstanding photocatalytic activity toward CO2 reduction [72]. They suggested that a large amount of Ti3+ defects introduced into the bulk of brookite nanoparticles increased the solar energy absorption and enhanced the photocatalytic activity [72].

sections.heading: 4.1. Zero-dimensional (0D)
sections.text:
Zero-dimensional TiO2 nanoparticles are the most basic and widely studied TiO2-related nanomaterials. They can be used as starting points for more complex materials with more specified and enhanced performance parameters. There are a variety of synthetic methods for TiO2 nanoparticles, such as sol–gel, micelle, hydrothermal, solvothermal, sonochemical, microwave, and chemical vapor deposition methods. The crystal sizes and crystal structures of TiO2 nanoparticles strongly depend on the synthesis parameters of temperature, solvent choice, additives, acidity, and aging during the solution-based preparation processes [87].
TiO2 nanomaterials that have been synthesized with the sol–gel method are generated via hydrolysis of a titanium precursor. This process normally proceeds via an acidcatalyzed hydrolysis step of titanium (IV) alkoxide followed by condensation. Sugimoto et  al reported the formation of TiO2 nanoparticles with different sizes and shapes using the sol–gel method [88, 89]. In their proposed synthesis a stock solution of Ti4+ was prepared by mixing titanium isopropoxide (TIPO) with triethanolamine (TEOA) at a molar ratio of TIPO: TEOA = 1:2 at room temperature, followed by the addition of water to make an aqueous stock solution of 0.50 mol dm−3 in Ti4+. Then, 10 ml of the stock solution was mixed with the same volume of doubly distilled water. The pH value of the solution can be adjusted by a HClO4 or NaOH solution. The final solution was aged at 100 °C for 24 h and 140 °C for 72 h to nucleate and grow titania particles. The particle size of the anatase TiO2 was increased from ca. 5 to 30 nm with pH increasing from 0.6 to 12 [88]. Interestingly, the morphology of the TiO2 nanoparticles was found to change from cuboidal to ellipsoidal at pH above 11 with TEOA [89]. Diethylenetriamine (DETA) also modified the particle shape to ellipsoidal above pH 9.5, and the aspect ratio was much higher than with TEOA [89]. TiO2 nanoparticles with sizes ranging from 2 to 10 nm can be synthesized using a modified sol–gel method at 50–100 °C [90].
Hydrothermal synthesis is another method that is widely used for the production of TiO2 nanoparticles. Ravishankar et al reported the synthesis of TiO2 nanoparticles by the ionic liquid-assisted hydrothermal method [91]. For their synthesis, 0.4 grams TiO2, 40 ml 2 M NaOH, and 1 g (BMI) CH3SO3 were treated at 130 °C for 2 d and then dried in an oven at 80 °C overnight [91]. The final products were spherical with an average diameter of 40–80 nm and excellent photocatalytic activity for the degradation of the trypan blue [91].
There are only a few reports of TiO2 nanoparticles with diameters <2 nm [92, 93] because they are very difficult to generate and the bandgap of such TiO2 nanoparticles will become wider due to the quantum-confinement effect. Tatsuya et  al synthesized size-defined crystalline TiO2 nanoparticles (2.0 ± 0.2 nm in diameter) by hydrolyzing a precursor, Ti-(acac)2(biphen), in the presence of a well-defined hollow Pd12L24 spherical end template—the template was removed by treating the sphere with a metal scavenger and then
J. Phys. D: Appl. Phys. 50 (2017) 193003
calcinating the sample at 500 °C for 3 h (figure 5(a)) [92]. The TiO2 nanoparticles are active in the photocatalytic degradation of methylene blue [92]. Satoh et al observed the quantum-confinement effect in the sub-nanometer TiO2 particles (figure 5(b)); the energy gap exhibits a blue shift with decreasing particle size [93], so the sub-nanometer size TiO2 nanoparticles are undesirable for most photocatalytic applications.

sections.heading: 4.2. One-dimensional (1D)
sections.text:
One-dimensional TiO2 structures, such as nanowires, nanorods, nanobelts, nanofibers, and nanotubes possess a large concentration of exposed active facets and exceptional electronic, optical and mechanical properties, making them viable candidates for a wide range of applications [94]. Aside from the nanotubes, all of the 1D structure possesses a solid structure; nanotubes have a hollow center. Nanorods are nanowires with a small aspect ratio (i.e. short nanowires) and typically appear rigid and straight. Nanobelts are special nanowires with a rectangular cross-section structure. Typical nanobelts structures are single crystals with well-defined side crystal facets. Nanofibers are nanowires that are very long and not very crystalline. Numerous routes have been explored to synthesize 1D TiO2 nanostructures from both bottom-up (solution-and vapor-based growth strategies) and top-down (oxidation and electrochemical etching techniques) approaches [95, 96].
The hydrothermal approach has been reported to be the best way for the preparation of 1D TiO2 nanostructures due to its simplicity and high production. Well-aligned TiO2 nanowires can be created by using TiO2 nanoparticle-seeded substrates in a hydrothermal system. Hwang et al synthesized rutile TiO2 nanowires with differing lengths of 0.28–1.8 µm on fluorine-doped tin oxide (FTO) substrates using the hydrothermal method [95]. A mixture of 5 ml H2O, 5 ml hydrochloric acid, 0.167 ml TIPO, and clean FTO/glass substrates were treated at 200 °C for different durations of time (50–150 min) and annealed at 400 °C for 1 h in air [95]. The nanowires prepared with this synthetic method show an increase in photocurrent with length and a maximum photocurrent of 0.73 mA cm−2 was measured (1.5 V versus
reversible hydrogen electrode (RHE)) for 1.8 µm long nanowires (figure 6) [95]. A Ti foil also can be used as the titanium source for the hydrothermal synthesis of TiO2 nanowires [97].
Nanorods are another common form of 1D TiO2 nanostructures which are usually prepared by the solvothermal method [98–101]. Cho et  al prepared single crystalline, branched TiO2 nanorods on the FTO via the hydrothermal method [98]. The branched TiO2 nanorods possess a cone shape with an average length of 90 nm, a diameter of 15 nm and a surface coverage density of around 1.6 × 1011 branches cm−2 [98]. Compared to TiO2 nanorods, the branched TiO2 nanorod array produced a photocurrent density of 0.83 mA cm−2 at 0.8 V versus RHE [98]. The enhanced photoelectrochemical efficiency demonstrated that (i) the branches improve charge separation and transport due to their small diameters, and (ii) a four-fold increase in surface area facilitates the hole transfer at the TiO2/electrolyte interface [98]. Fakharuddin et al synthesized TiO2 nanorods with DI water, HCl (37%), and TIPO at 150 °C for 4–5 h in an electric oven. The FTOs were placed in an autoclave with the conducting side facing down at an angle ~45° [99]. The TiO2 nanorods have an average diameter of ~100 nm and a length of ~500–550 nm.
There are several approaches to synthesis of TiO2 nanobelts, such as hydrothermal processes [102, 103], electrochemical anodization [104], and metalorganic chemical vapor deposition [105]. The hydrothermal method, including the alkaline and acid hydrothermal processes, can be an effective and facile approach to the formation of highly crystallized TiO2 nanobelts. In a typical alkali-hydrothermal procedure, the titanium precursor is first dispersed into a NaOH aqueous solution with a concentration of 10 M and then hydrothermally heated at 180–200 °C for at least 12 h [94]. The size and morphology of the TiO2 nanobelts can be tuned by adding a surfactant. For the acid hydrothermal process, it is completely different. The nature of the method is delicate control of the rate of hydrolysis of the titanium precursor in acid conditions, resulting in the formation of TiO2 nanobelts with the [0 0 1] growth direction. Zhang et  al prepared rutile TiO2 nanobelts by applying the hydrothermal method at high acid concentrations (9–10 M);
in their synthesis, tetrabutyl titanate was homogenously mixed with 9–10 M HCl aqueous solution, and then treated at 180 °C for 2 h [102]. Cha et  al also used a high acid concentration (12 M HCl) to prepare TiO2 nanobelts [106]. Electrochemical anodization is a simple method to synthesis TiO2 nanobelts, and the morphology of the formed TiO2 nanobelts can be controlled by the experimental parameters such as applied voltage and concentrations. Chen et al synthesized TiO2 nanobelts by electrochemical anodization at 60 V for 3 h [104]. An electrolyte containing ethylene glycol, ammonium fluoride (NH4F, 0.5 wt%), and water (5 vol%) was used [104]. They found that calcination temperatures had a great effect on the crystal phase and photocatalytic activity [104]. The sample calcined at 550 °C showed the highest photocatalytic performance [104].
TiO2 nanofibers are typically prepared from the electrospinning of a mixture of titanium alkoxide and a polymer, such as polyvinylpyrrolidone (PVP), with a subsequent calcination step employed to remove the polymer and crystallize the TiO2 [107, 108]. Choi et al prepared mesoporous TiO2 nanofibers and showed that the enhanced photocatalytic activity was due to their porosity and nanofiber alignment, two properties that reduce the recombination of electron–hole pairs through inter particle charge transfer along the nanofiber framework [107]. Zhang et  al prepared hollow mesoporous TiO2 nanofibers by co-axial electrospinning of a titanium tetraisopropoxide (TTIP) solution with two immiscible polymers, polyethylene oxide (PEO) and PVP, using a core–shell spinneret, followed by annealing at 450 °C [109]. The annealed mesoporous TiO2 nanofibers had a hollow structure with an average diameter of 130 nm and showed enhanced photocatalytic activity for the degradation of rhodamine dye [109].
TiO2 nanotubes are usually fabricated by anodization, which is typically conducted in solution containing a fluoride electrolyte (e.g. HF and NH4F) or organic component (ethylene glycol, dimethyl sulfoxide, and glycerol). The diameter of TiO2 nanotubes can be adjusted by the anodization potential (from 10 to 600 nm) [110], and the length can be manipulated to stretch from 1 µm to longer than 100 µm by changing
the anodization electrolyte or anodization time [111]. Their photoelectrochemical performance strongly depends on their morphological properties (e.g. tube diameter, inter-tubular distance, and tube wall thickness). For example, Liu et  al prepared double-wall TiO2 nanotubes by anodization in an organic electrolyte containing 1-butyl-3-methylimidazolium tetrafluoroborate [73]. The obtained TiO2 nanotubes exhibited strong absorption in the range of 400–800 nm and significant photocatalytic activity under sunlight [73]. Schmuki’s group prepared bamboo-type nanotubes by alternating the voltage anodization of Ti in an electrolyte consisting of 0.2 mol l−1 HF in ethylene glycol [112]. Significantly improved photocatalytic efficiency was reported by Li’s group with a facile electrochemical etching method to selectively remove the outer walls of anodic TiO2 nanotubes to separate single-walled TiO2 nanotubes [74].

sections.heading: 4.3. 2D
sections.text: Nanosheets are a common form of 2D TiO2 nanostructures which are typically prepared by exfoliation of layered titanates or via the hydrothermal process. The initial layer of these titanates significantly affects the nanosheets in terms of crystallinity, composition, size, and functionality [113]. A number of TiO2 nanosheets have been obtained by exfoliating various layered compounds. Leng et al reported a surfactantassisted exfoliation method to prepare TiO2 nanosheets [114]. Anatase TiO2 nanoparticles were used as the raw material and tetrabutylammonium hydroxide (TBAOH) as the surfactant, and the preparation process was conducted in an alkaline solution at 130 °C for 24 h [114]. Hu et al prepared TiO2 nanosheets by a one-step solvothermal method [115]. In this process, tetrabutyl titanate (2 ml), hydrofluoric acid (0.8 ml), and n-propanol (25 ml) were treated at 180 °C for 20 h [115]. The length and width of the nanosheets was 1.5–2 µm and the thickness of that was only 2–4 nm [115]. The TiO2 nanosheet showed enhanced photocatalytic performance in the degradation of Rhodamine B [115].

sections.heading: 4.4. 3D
sections.text:
3D TiO2 nanomaterials such as porous spheres, shells, nanoflowers, and hierarchical superstructures have also been reported as efficient photocatalysts [116–124]. These 3D structures not only possess a large specific surface area, but also exceptional electronic, optical, and photocatalytic properties. Several reviews have reported various applications of 3D TiO2 nanomaterials in photocatalysis, photoelectrochemistry, solar cells, and so on [121].
Liu et  al prepared 3D mesoporous ‘posy bouquet’ TiO2 superstructures by a novel method known as confinedmicromulsion self-assembly (figure 7) [118]. The obtained 3D mesoporous TiO2 superstructures had well-defined floral topologies, oriented hexagonal mesochannels, high accessible surface area (134–148 m2 g−1), large pore volume (0.48–0.51 cm3 g−1), and single-crystalline anatase walls with dominant (0 0 1) active facets [118]. Yu et al synthesized 3D ‘orchid’ TiO2 nanowire networks using the hydrothermal method [116]. 3D TiO2 nanomesh can also be synthesized via the hydrothermal method using NaOH and P25 as the reactive agents [123]. Anodization is another common method to prepared 3D nanomaterials on the substrate. The 3D ‘pine branch’ structure TiO2 films were obtained by anodizing in an ethylene glycol solution containing HNO3 (1 wt%) and water (1 wt%) at 40 V for 10 min [32, 51]. The obtained TiO2 films
exhibited excellent optical absorption capacity in the ultraviolet and visible ranges, as well as demonstrated high photoelectrocatalytic activity and stability in dye degradation and hydrogen generation [32, 51].

sections.heading: 4.5. Facet-tailored
sections.text:
In recent years greater attention has been focused on studying facet-tailored TiO2 materials due to the high proportion of high-index facets present on the crystal surface. Taking anatase TiO2 for example, it has facets (arranged from highest to lowest surface energy quantities) of {1 1 0} (1.09 J m−2), {0 0 1} (0.90 J m−2), {0 1 0} (0.53 J m−2), and the {1 0 1} facet (0.44 J m−2) [125]. The surface energy has a close relationship to the intrinsic density of under-coordinated Ti atoms [126]. {1 0 1} facets have the lowest surface energy and therefore are the most stable, which are commonly dominant on spherical or irregular particles. {0 1 0} facets were theoretically predicted that they could dominate the crystal shape under the effect from basic solution chemistry, which directed some syntheses of anataste TiO2 with partial {0 1 0} facets [127]. {1 1 0} facets are seldom synthesized largely because of its high surface energy and extreme instability. The first example was reported to synthesize {1 0 1}{0 0 1} major and {1 1 0} minor anatase crystals by hydrothermally treating Ti powder
in a mixed HF and H2O2 environment [128]. Among them, {0 0 1} facets have attracted major research interest and many studies have been reported to fabricate a high {0 0 1} proportion of TiO2 crystals [129–131]. These {0 0 1} facets not only possess superior surface energy and high photocatalytic capability, but are also predicted to have promising surface properties such as the capability to dissociatively adsorb water molecules and anchor dye molecules. Yang et al successfully synthesized micro-anatase single crystals with a {0 0 1} facet percentage reaching up to 47%, accomplished with the hydrothermal method—TiF4 was the Ti precursor and HF was the morphology controlling agent in this synthesis [132]. Facettailored rutile [133–135] and brookite [136, 137] have also been synthesized and investigated.
Faceted TiO2 materials can be synthesized through various strategies, including wet chemistry [132, 138–142], gas oxidation [143], and topotactic transformation. Among them, the more commonly used wet chemistry-based hydrothermal or solvothermal methods manipulate the nucleation and control the growth rate along different orientations to effectively tailor the exposure of desirable crystal facets. Under equilibrium states, high surface energy facets such as anatase {0 0 1} have more rapid growth rates. As a result, only a small proportion of them remain in the final crystals. To modulate the ratio of different facets and preserve desirable facets, appropriate organic molecules, inorganic ions, or a combination of the two are selectively adsorbed onto these crystal surface as ‘capping agents’ to reduce their surface energies and control the growth rates [132, 144], as shown in figure 8 [145]. Modification of facet-tailored TiO2 like doping [146] and synthesizing faceted composites [135, 147, 148] have also been explored to further optimize their optical adsorption and electronic properties.
In terms of photocatalysis, crystal facet tailoring can confer unique properties to TiO2 photocatalysts. High performance
photocatalysis not only depends on the high catalytic activity sites introduced by high surface energy facets, but also on the absorption efficiency of reactant molecules such as organic compounds, water, or CO2, onto TiO2 photocatalysts before surface charge transfer takes place, and facile manipulation of electron band structures to meet the redox potential and charge transfer requirements for water splitting [149] and CO2 reduction [127, 150].
As previously discussed, strong oxidizers can be generated through a series of photo excitation-induced reactions, but they usually have poor reactant selectivity. In considering the many extrinsic influences such as reactant molecule structure, size, and polarity (not to mention surface properties and solvent choice), facet-tailored TiO2 is able to catalyze the desired reactions because its atomic surface structure selects for the adsorption and desorption of particular reactants and their intermediates [151]. For example, Liu and coworkers have synthesized hollow TiO2 microspheres composed of anatase polyhedra with 20% exposed {0 0 1} facets that have shown tunable photocatalytic selectivity for the decomposition of azo dyes in water [152]. When fluorinated, the material exhibited preferred degradation of methyl orange over methylene blue; when treated with a NaOH wash or 600 °C calcination, the surface favored the adsorption of methylene blue due to its ‘hydroxylized’ environment. In the case of Zhou et al, their research group compared the formaldehyde adsorption performance on F−, Cl−, and OH−-modified anatase TiO2 nanosheets (that also had exposed {0 0 1} facets) and found that all three anions could weaken the interaction between formaldehyde and material surface. The OH− anion, however, showed superior performance because it captured a hydrogen atom from formaldehyde to form a formyl group and H2O, which reduced the overall energy of formaldehyde adsorption and provided extra active centers [153].
In contrast to the photocatalytic decomposition that is dominated by the oxidation half-reaction, photocatalytic overall water splitting and aqueous CO2 reduction require both oxidation and reduction half reactions to be simultaneously efficient. Both half-reactions can be designed and tuned with facet-tailored TiO2 since it can also affect the surface electronic structure that determines the redox potentials of photoexcitons. Liu et al synthesized boron-doped anatase TiO2 microspheres with dominant {0 0 1} facets to study the influence of heteroatom spatial distribution on their photocatalytic hydrogen (reduction half reaction) and oxygen (oxidation half reaction) evolution preferences [64]. When the shell of microspheres is boronfree, photocatalytic hydrogen evolution is favored; oxygen evolution is favored when removing boron from the core to the shell. This ‘switch’ is a result of a downward shift of the electronic band edges of the shell, originating from extra electrons being introduced in the interstitial region of the material. Moreover, faceted TiO2 can spatially separate the photoexcited electron–hole pairs with its different facets, each facet playing its unique part in the rational design of photocatalysts and photoelectrodes. For example, {1 0 1}/{0 0 1} facets for anatase and {1 1 1}/{0 0 1} for rutile were applied as reduction/oxidation reaction sites, respectively [154]. Conventionally irregular faceted brookite TiO2 is photoinactive. However, as shown in figure 9, Lin and coworkers prepared excellent brookite TiO2 single crystalline nanosheets photocatalysts that contained four {2 1 0} facets and two {1 0 1} facets that acted as reduction sites, as well as two {2 0 1} facets that acted as oxidation sites [155]. Exposure of high energy facets effectively suppressed charge carrier combination recombination, thus improving brookite’s photocatalytic performance.

sections.heading: 4.6. Defect-rich
sections.text:
The defects of Ti3+ and oxygen vacancies play important roles in narrowing the bandgap of TiO2 such as active centers and defect energy levels, which can be detected by electron spin
resonance spectroscopy (ESR) or electron paramagnetic resonance spectroscopy (EPR) since the paramagnetic Ti3+ has a g-value of 1.94–1.99 and the oxygen vacancies appear at 2.004. Su et  al prepared the hydrogenated TiO2 by annealing TiO2 in H2/N2 mixed gas at 300–600 °C and observed the existence of oxygen vacancy in their spectroscopic analyses [156]. The intensity of the signals for these hydrogenated samples increased with the treated temperature [156]. This phenomenon can also be witnessed in the defects of self-doped samples as well. Ti3+ self-doped TiO2 nanotube arrays were fabricated via the combination of the two-step electrochemical anodization method and the electrochemical reduction approach [157]. Two strong signals at around g = 1.98 and g = 2.00 corresponding to Ti3+ and oxygen vacancies were observed, respectively [157]. Ti3+ self-doping introduced new inter band states, facilitated the separation of photogenerated electron–hole pairs, and increased the carrier density, leading to improved charge transfer at the semiconductor–electrolyte interface [157]. Liu et al reported that the TiO2 film obtained by anodizing in an electrolyte containing HNO3–H2Oethylene glycol solution possessed Ti3+ and oxygen vacancies [32, 51]. This defect-rich TiO2 film showed strong and broad optical absorption from 200 to 2500 nm. Owing to this strong absorption and rapid transport of photogenerated electrons, the film exhibited high photoelectrocatalytic efficiency under sunlight [32, 51].

sections.heading: 4.7. Composited
sections.text:
TiO2 composite structures can create and tune other properties such as mid-bandgap electronic states which can alter charge migration or produce a red shift in the absorption spectrum. Further, the formation of heterojunctions between TiO2 and other materials can enhance visible light absorption by facilitating the charge separation of TiO2. Some examples of these TiO2 composites include metal-metal oxide, noble metal-metal oxide, nonoxide-semiconductor, and carbon TiO2 composites.
Topical Review
Li et al synthesized a series of composites including ZrO2, CeO2 and TiO2 by the evaporation-induced self-assembly method [158]. With Pluronic P123 used as a surfactant, a solution of ethanol containing Ce(NO3)3, ZrOCl2 · 8H2O, and titanium n-butoxide was reacted, dried, and calcinated at 500 °C [158]. The mesoporous ZrO2–CeO2–TiO2 demonstrated increased photocatalytic activity in comparison to pristine TiO2 in the decomposition of Rhodamine B under visible light irradiation [158].
Nguyen-Phan et al synthesized a RuO2/TiO2 heterostructure by immobilizing minute quantities of RuO2 onto 1D TiO2 nanorods [159]. Titanium n-butoxide (7 ml) and hydrochloric acid (35 wt%, 7 ml) were treated at 105 °C for 11 h, the TiO2 rods were obtained after calcinations at 200 °C for 2 h. The impregnation of RuO2 was carried out by dropwise addition of an appropriate concentration of 5 ml aqueous RuCl3 · xH2O solution at 90 °C [159]. These titanium/rubidium composites exhibited superior visible-light driven H2 generation activity, 0.1 wt% of RuO2 being the optimal loading amount to achieve the highest H2 evolved rate [159]. Nguyen-Phan et al suggest that the surface defects, bandgap narrowing, visible photoresponse, and favorable upward band bending at the heterointerface drastically facilitated the transfer and separation of photogenerated charge carriers [159].
TiO2/g-C3N4 composite materials are mechanically prepared though a process known as ‘ball milling’, followed by further calcination, ultrasonic dispersion, and impregnation by using the prepared g-C3N4 and TiO2 as precursors [160]. Unfortunately, the combination of TiO2 and g-C3N4 is not strong enough because of these mechanical mixing methods. Li et  al prepared TiO2/g-C3N4 heterojunctions by one-step calcinations of H2Ti3O7 nanotubes and melamine [35]. In this procedure, H2Ti3O7 nanotubes (1.0 g) and proportional amounts of melamine were mixed in 100 ml of water, followed by an ultrasonic treatment for 30 min, stirred for 4 h, then annealed at 520 °C for 4 h in a muffle furnace [35]. The resulting TiO2/g-C3N4 heterojunctions showed an enhanced photocatalytic performance, suggesting that the established heterojunction between the interfaces of TiO2 nanoparticles and g-C3N4 nanosheets, as well as the introduced Ti3+, led to the rapid electron transfer rate and improved photoinduced electron–hole pair’s separation efficiency [35]. Yu et  al prepared carbon quantum dots/TiO2 composites via a one-step hydrothermal reaction at 140 °C for 4 h [161]. The resulting carbon quant um dots/TiO2 composites exhibited efficient photocatalytic H2 evolution activity, which is ~4 times higher than that of pure P25 under UV–Vis light irradiation [161]. The carbon quant um dots act as photosensitizer to sensitize P25 into a visible light responsive ‘dyade’ structure, in which the photogenerated electrons transfer from excited carbon quant um dots and then react with protons for H2 generating [161].

sections.heading: 4.8. Hydrogenated
sections.text:
In 2011, Chen and coworkers reported that hydrogenated TiO2 (‘black’ TiO2) had a narrowed bandgap of about 1.0 eV and exhibited substantial photocatalytic capability [162]. This discovery prompted worldwide research interest in black TiO2
nanomaterials. Since this discovery there have been a variety of proposed synthetic methods such as hydrogenation (including hydrogen thermal treatment and [163–167] hydrogen plasma methods [168–172]), chemical reduction (utilizing Al, Mg, NaBH4, and NaH as reducing agents) [40, 173–178], chemical oxidation [72, 179], electrochemical reduction/oxidation [157, 180–184], and a variety of other physical methods (ultrasonication, pulsed-laser irradiation) [185, 186]. Among them, the hydrogenation process is the most simple and straightforward method to prepare black TiO2. Here, the ‘hydrogenation process’ refers to the heating of a TiO2 sample under a hydrogen-containing atmosphere (or hydrogen plasma) for a certain period of time and at varying temperatures [187].
Chen et  al prepared black TiO2 nanoparticles by reacting pure white TiO2 nanoparticles under a 20.0-bar pure H2 atmosphere at about 200 °C for 5 d [162]. The resulting black TiO2 samples had a well-crystallized lattice core surrounded by a disordered shell structure [162]. The formation of this ‘disordered shell’ could be attributed to the formation of Ti–H and O–H bonds due to the hydrogen doping, and may be responsible for the creation of ‘mid-gap’ states in the material’s electronic structure and its black color [162]. In addition to its broad optical absorption, black TiO2 demonstrated higher photocatalytic activity in generating H2 from a watermethanol solution and decomposing methylene blue and phenol [162]. Ordered mesoporous black TiO2 materials were obtained via hydrogenation at 500 °C for 3 h under normal pressure conditions with a constant heating rate of 5 °C min−1 (figure 10(a)) [164]. The absorption spectra of the ordered mesoporous black TiO2 materials demonstrated augmented light absorption in the visible and infrared light regions; the bandgap of the ordered mesoporous black TiO2 materials narrowed to be about 2.82 eV [164].
The hydrogenation temperature and time have a great influence on the concentration of Ti3+ defects and oxygen vacancies [188]. Yu et al prepared hydrogenated TiO2 nanosheets under a H2 gas flow (50 sccm) at atmospheric pressure in a quartz tube at 500–700 °C for a fixed period of time (0.5–1 h) [188]. The color of the obtained samples changed from white to blue, then finally to gray [188]. Cai et al also prepared the black TiO2 (B)-anatase heterophase under varying hydrogenation temperatures, comparing the photocatalytic performance for each temperature trial [165]. As shown in figure  10(b), the sample H-650 exhibits the highest hydrogen evolution rate of ~580 µmol h−1 with 0.02 g of photocatalyst. Both the pure TiO2 (B) phase (H-400, ~107 µmol h−1) and the anatase phase (H-750, ~452 µmol h−1) show much lower activity than H-650. All the hydrogenated samples have higher photocatalytic activities than that of the sample treated in pure nitrogen atmosphere at 650 °C (N-650) [165]. This data suggests that the superior performance of the H-650 can be attributed to the synergistic effect of the hydrogenation-induced, surfacedisordered shell, as well as the TiO2 (B)-anatase heterophase junction [165].
The hydrogenation atmosphere also has a great influence on the color and performance of the TiO2 nanomaterials. The color of hydrogenated anatase TiO2 nanotubes were changed
J. Phys. D: Appl. Phys. 50 (2017) 193003
under the following different atmospheres: (i) air; (ii) an atmosphere containing Ar (Ar) or a H2/Ar mixture (H2/Ar); (iii) a high-pressure, high-temperature H2atmosphere (20 bar, 500 °C for 1 h); and (iv) a high-pressure atmosphere but mildtemperature H2 atmosphere (H2, 20 bar, 200 °C for 5 d) [167]. After the reduction treatments, the color of TiO2 was changed from white to black (Ar/H2), deep purple (Ar), light blue (H2, 500 °C for 1 h), and gray (H2, 200 °C for 5 d) [167].
Wang and Yan et  al prepared hydrogenated black TiO2 nanoparticles in hydrogen plasma. Their black TiO2 nanoparticles showed a significant absorption in the visible and near-infrared regions [172, 189]. An et al reported that hydrogenated TiO2 photocatalysts prepared by hydrogen plasma treatment displayed high anatase/brookite bicrystallinity and extended the absorption spectra from the ultraviolet to visible range [169]. The black nanoporous TiO2 displayed strong visible absorption and excellent degradation efficiencies for the azo dye [169]. Such superior photocatalytic performance of H-TiO2 was attributed to its narrowed bandgap, which is supported by the formation of many ·OH free radicals and the large surface area of H-TiO2 [169]. Wang et  al compared the hydrogen thermal and plasma treatment on the formation of black TiO2 nanowire arrays [190]. The pristine TiO2 nanowire arrays were prepared by the hydrothermal method [190]. Both the hydrogen thermal and plasma treatment TiO2 nanowire arrays exhibited black color and increased absorption in the visible-light region, especially the black TiO2 sample prepared by the hydrothermal method [190].
Recently, Xu et al reported an extremely facile method to prepare hydrogenated TiO2, which was performed with doping a slight amount of Pd at room temperature under pressureless H2 or H2/O2 gas flow within several minutes [191]. This Pd-catalyzed hydrogenation strategy is based on that H2 could spontaneously dissociate on the Pd surface to generate highly active atomic hydrogen species [H], which would diffuse into and interact with the TiO2 lattice to generate durable point defects (Ti3+, oxygen vacancies) and even surface disorder
[191]. The defects of Ti3+, oxygen vacancies in TiO2 remarkably narrowed the bandgap and improved the solar energy utilization [191].

sections.heading: 5. Summary and perspective
sections.text:
In summary, a lot of progress has been made in the development of TiO2 photocatalysts; some of these achievements include an ever-developing understanding of its photocatalytic mechanism and its various methods of synthesis. TiO2 nanomaterials with different sizes, shapes, and dimensions have been successfully synthesized along with the manipulation of their facets, defects, and compositions. Among these methods, crystal facet engineering has recently become a very promising method for TiO2 synthesis, and more research is underway to fully understand how these facets can be altered to optimize material properties. With the even more recent discovery of hydrogenation methods, however, our interests have extended beyond the traditional doping, compositing, and defect-engineering. The relationship between the photocatalytic activity and the photocatalyst is still a complicated, albeit interesting, topic, partially due to the complex nature of the photocatalytic process and the poor control of the synthesis of TiO2 photocatalysts. Unlike molecular photocatalysts which have identical structures and compositions, inorganic semiconductor photocatalysts are naturally more complicated as they normally have a mixture of different sizes, shapes, and morphologies with various defects and surface facets; their optical and electronic properties vary with these factors. A clearer understanding of the photocatalytic activity and the properties of TiO2 as a photocatalyst could be achieved if the size, shape, morphology, defect arrangements, and surface facets could be precisely manipulated. Unfortunately for materials scientists, synthetic chemistry has not quite reached that point. Our research group, however, remains optimistic in the search for an undisputed connection between a material’s properties, its synthesis method, and its catalytic performance.

metadata.abstractText: Titanium dioxide (TiO2) has been long regarded as one of the more promising photocatalysts to remove environmental pollution and to generate hydrogen from water under sunlight irradiation via photocatalysis. TiO2 is environmentally benign and thus is considered a ‘green’ catalyst. In this review we present a short introduction to the physical and electronic properties of TiO2, its photocatalytic mechanisms, and some recent examples of various TiO2 materials used for photocatalysis; these examples include 0, 1, 2, 3D, faceted, defected, composited, and hydrogenated TiO2 materials.
